Description: Tamarisk wooden hare-shaped headrest: carved in one piece.
Curator's comments: As a desert creature, the hare was considered to be a creature of chaos and potentially dangerous. The animal's alertness, fleetness and fertility have been suggested as positive symbolic meanings, as well as a Greek and Roman belief, possibly also held by the Egyptians, that it slept with its eyes open. Although this last trait would seem especially fitting for a headrest animal, this hare's eyes appear to be almost closed. Bibliography: T. Phillips [ed.], 'Africa' (London, 1995), p. 90 [1.53] = T. Phillips [ed.], 'Afrika' (Berlin, 1996), p.90 [1.53]; 'Temples and Tombs' [exhibition catalogue] (American Federation of Arts, 2006), 118, cat no. 75.
Bibliographic references: Russmann 2001 / Eternal Egypt: Masterworks of Ancient Art from the British Museum (73)
Exhibition history: 1995/6 Oct-Jan, Royal Academy of Arts, Africa: The Art of a Continent 1996 Mar-May, Berlin, Martin Gropius Bau, Africa: The Art of a Continent 1996 May-Sep, New York, Guggenheim Museum, Africa: The Art of a Continent 1998/9 Oct-Jun, South Carolina, The Charleston Museum, Queens Commoners of the New Kingdom 2006 7 Sept-26 Nov, Oklahoma City Museum of Art, Temples & Tombs 2006 21 Dec-2007 18 Mar, Jackonsville, Cummer Museum of Art & Gardens, Temples & Tombs 2007 15 Apr-8 Jul, Raleigh, North Carolina Museum of Art, Temples & Tombs 2007 16 Nov-2008 10 Feb, New Mexico, Albuquerque Museum, Temples & Tombs
